clinical_study.brief_title: Primary Urethral Realignment vs. Suprapubic Cystostomy for Initial Management of Pediatric Pelvic Fracture Urethral Injury
clinical_study.official_title: Primary Urethral Realignment vs. Suprapubic Cystostomy for Initial Management of Pelvic Fracture Urethral Injury in Children: Randomized Clinical Trial

brief_summary.textblock:
It is prospective randomized comparative clinical trial comparing primary urethral realignment vs. suprapubic cystostomy in initial management of pediatric pelvic fracture urethral injury regarding:
1. The success rate after initial intervention.
2. The need for urethroplasty in the failed realignment group and cystostomy group.
3. The success rate of urethroplasty in the failed realignment group and cystostomy group.

primary_outcome.measure: The success rate after initial intervention (realignment or suprapubic cystostomy).
primary_outcome.description: The fulfillment of success criteria after initial intervention which includes good stream, no postvoid residual urine, normal Qmax for age and free retrograde urethrogram

secondary_outcome.measure: The success rate of urethroplasty in both groups.
secondary_outcome.description: The surgical outcome of urethroplasty in cases of children with posterior urethral stricture after failed realignment or suprapubic cystostomy.

secondary_outcome.measure: The need for urethroplasty in both groups.
secondary_outcome.description: Comparison of the need for urethroplasty in children with failed realignment or suprapubic cystostomy.

intervention.description: Endoscopic realignment of rupture urethra over a urethral catheter
Percutaneous cystostomy catheter will be inserted under sonographic guidance

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Male children less than 18 years presenting with pelvic fracture urethral injury
Exclusion Criteria:
- Associated bladder neck injury.
- Associated rectal injury.
- Late presentation >2weeks since trauma.
- History of previous urethral intervention.
